content: One of the shittiest parts about depression is that it (and all mental illness) still carries such a stigma, even in our “enlightened” age. If you exhibit your symptoms, it *might* be demons, we’re still not quite sure but we do think it’s almost positively contagious. And if you don’t exhibit your symptoms, we can pretend that you don’t have demons (maybe). Maybe we should just call depression “diabetes”; it would sure get a better response. With the ever-increasing numbers of new diagnoses for depression in our society…we’d better get rid of the stigma. If we don’t, we’re going to have to bell/book/candle Grandmom and the surly teenagers; our boss, co-workers and the barista that makes our macho super grande latte frappacino, soy, extra caramel syrup and 2 espresso shots. When people talk about exercise, they’re really saying “exorcise”; it will probably end up being a drive-thru service. Hang in there; you’ve got this even when you think your depression is the one in charge. It’s not. But it is a nearly fail-safe method of finding out who your real friends are — because they love you, no matter what. And of course, the rest of us depressedly, clinically depressed people are here for you as well. Peace and blessings!
